item.title: Supreme Court Asked to Hear Challenge to Trump’s Global Tariffs
item.description: The US Supreme Court was asked for the first time to consider striking down President Donald Trump’s most sweeping tariffs, putting the justices in the middle of a high-stakes fight with worldwide economic implications.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The U.S. Supreme Court in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Monday, Oct. 4, 2021. The court's conservative wing offers a menu of opportunities to exploit its 6-3 majority, and give Republicans the type of payoff they envisioned when they pushed through Justice Amy Coney Barrett's Senate confirmation just before the 2020 election.

item.title: G-7 Leaders’ Summit in Canada Continues Without Trump

media:content.media:description: A working session during the G7 Summit in Kananaskis, Alberta, on June 17.

item.title: Europe Pitches Stability to Bond Investors Wary of US Turbulence
item.description: Finance officials from across Europe are touting their bond markets as a haven from US volatility in a bid to attract global investors rethinking their dollar allocations.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ritchie

media:content.media:description: Skyscrapers and commercial buildings, beyond Tower Bridge, in the City of London, UK, on Monday, June 2, 2025. At least 10% of the UK's wealthy non-dom population have left the country following tighter tax rules introduced by Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s Labour government, according to a new report authored by a former Treasury economist. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: IMF Met With Emerging-Market Creditors on Debt Rework Strategies
item.description: A group of International Monetary Fund officials met private creditors last week in London, as part of the multilateral lender’s work to publish a new report on sovereign debt restructurings in emerging markets, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Jorgelina Do Rosario

media:content.media:description: International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank Fall meetings signage outside the IMF headquarters in Washington, DC, US, on Sunday, Oct. 20, 2024.

item.title: Nassim Taleb Says Trump’s Approach to Tariffs ‘Makes No Sense’
item.description: The Black Swan author Nassim Taleb said President Donald Trump’s approach to tariffs will depress US gross domestic product and could soon lead to labor shortages.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Cantrell, Sonali Basak

media:content.media:description: Nassim Nicholas Taleb, senior scientific advisor at Universa, speaks during the Bloomberg Invest event in New York, US, on Thursday, June 8, 2023. The conference invites investors, from institutional and high-net worth to private and retail, to leave with fresh perspective and crucial insight for 2023 and beyond.

item.title: US Homebuilder Sentiment Drops to Lowest Level Since End of 2022
item.description: Confidence among US homebuilders fell in June to the lowest level since December 2022, with potential buyers deterred by high mortgage rates and anxiety about tariffs and the economy.
item.dc:creator: Michael Sasso

media:content.media:description: Workers install kitchen cabinets inside a home under construction in Loudonville, New York.

item.title: US Retail Sales Drop for Second Month as Tariff Anxiety Sets In
item.description: US retail sales fell for a second straight month in May, suggesting anxiety over tariffs and personal finances prompted consumers to pull back after an early-year spending rush.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette

item.title: Tax Bill Lacks Votes as Senate Aims for Deals on SALT, Medicaid
item.description: Republican leaders are aiming for quick negotiations over needed changes to the newly unveiled Senate tax bill which lacks the votes to secure majorities in both chambers as written.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Alicia Diaz

item.title: Ireland Removes Pay Caps for AIB and PTSB Executives
item.description: Salary caps for executives at AIB Group Plc and Permanent TSB Group Plc will be removed, Ireland’s Minister for Finance Paschal Donohoe said.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher, Jennifer Duggan

media:content.media:description: An Allied Irish Banks bank branch in Dublin.

item.title: Trump’s Latest Attack on Fed Zooms In on Surging Debt Costs
item.description: Donald Trump is putting new spin on his months-long call for the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates: It’s important for bringing down the cost of government debt.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran

item.title: US Industrial Output Declines for Second Time in Three Months
item.description: US industrial production fell in May for the second time in three months as utility output declined and manufacturers struggled for traction against a backdrop of cooler demand.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle

media:content.media:description: A work assembles a mid-size vehicle at a manufacturing plant in Canton, Mississippi.

item.title: Noisy Data Muddles Inflation Picture Ahead of BOE Decision
item.description: UK inflation is expected to cool in figures due to be released Wednesday, but a lower number may to do little to ease uncertainty about price pressures in the British economy amid fresh questions about the official data.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: May’s inflation reading arrives a day before the BOE announces its interest-rate decision. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Reeves Says UK Won’t Lift Defense Budget Again This Parliament
item.description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves has said any further rise to the UK’s budget for defense won’t come until the next parliament, raising questions about how the government will meet NATO spending commitments.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves meets defense suppliers at RAF Northolt, UK, in March. Photographer: Dan Kitwood/Getty Images

item.title: ECB Amends Bank Capital Reviews Amid Extreme Weather Risks
item.description: The European Central Bank is embedding climate risk into regular reviews of how well banks can absorb losses, marking a new chapter in its supervisory approach.
item.dc:creator: Frances Schwartzkopff

media:content.media:description: Homes beside a riverbed destroyed after flash floods in Chiva, Spain in 2024.

item.title: Australia ‘Not Resilient Enough’ to World Turmoil, Chalmers Says
item.description: Australia’s economy and budget need further ballast to withstand the latest rounds of global volatility, Treasurer Jim Chalmers said, even as he highlighted that the nation is better positioned than many developed-world counterparts.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Jim Chalmers

item.title: Trump’s Trade Deal With the UK Leaves Steel Tariffs Unresolved
item.description: Keir Starmer stooping to recover the latest iteration of the UK’s trade agreement with President Donald Trump was an awkward symbol of the current shape of the negotiations. The deal must continually be dealt with. And the British prime minister will have do most of the bending.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Scott

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer picks up papers dropped by Donald Trump in Kananaskis, Canada, on June 16. Photographer: Pool/Getty Images North America

item.title: German Investor Confidence Jumps as Fiscal Boost Outweighs Trade
item.description: Investor confidence in Germany’s economy improved more than anticipated as a forthcoming surge in public spending outweighs fears over looming US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

item.title: Sweden’s Faltering Growth May Force Another Rate Cut
item.description: The Riksbank may be about to restart a cycle of interest-rate-cutting that officials had signaled to be over as recently as March.
item.dc:creator: Ott Ummelas, Charlie Duxbury

item.title: Trump, Starmer Agree to Implement Tariff-Cutting Trade Deal
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer reached an agreement with US President Donald Trump to implement some main elements of the trade deal announced last month to lower US tariffs on key British exports and raise UK quotas on certain American agricultural products.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump meets with Britain's Prime Minister Keir Starmer on the sidelines of the G7 Summit in Kananaskis, Canada, on June 16. Photographer: Mark Schiefelbein/AP Photo

item.title: BOJ to Slow Bond Market Withdrawal After Standing Pat on Rates
item.description: The Bank of Japan unveiled a plan to step back from the bond market at a slower pace from next year to ensure market stability while sticking to a path of normalization that includes the possibility of more rate hikes.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka, Sumio Ito

item.title: Chile Set to Hold Key Rate, Hint at Future Cuts: Decision Guide
item.description: Chile’s central bank will likely hold its key interest rate steady Tuesday, while signaling plans to resume monetary easing as global headwinds crimp growth and local inflation slows toward target.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

item.title: ECB Has Found ‘Equilibrium’ on Rates, Prices, Growth, Stournaras Says
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Yannis Stournaras says it seems the euro area has reached an equilibrium when it comes to inflation, banking-sector developments and economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Sotiris Nikas

item.title: Modi Misses Chance to Push for US Trade Deal as Trump Leaves G-7
item.description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi had no opportunity to push for a US trade deal with Donald Trump after the American president left the Group of Seven leaders’ summit early, a potential setback for New Delhi as recent tariff negotiations hit hurdles.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, center, arrives at Calgary Airport on June 16. Photographer: Dave Chidley/Getty Images

item.title: RBI Governor Seeks to Clear Up Market Confusion on Rate Outlook
item.description: India’s central bank may have space for further policy easing if inflation undershoots its projections, said Governor Sanjay Malhotra, seeking to address market confusion sparked by his earlier remarks that the authority has limited room for easing.
item.dc:creator: Subhadip Sircar, Bhaskar Dutta, Anup Roy

media:content.media:description: Sanjay Malhotra

item.title: Irish State Exits AIB, Putting Bank Into Private Ownership
item.description: The Irish state has disposed of the remainder of its shareholding in AIB Group plc, putting the bank into private ownership.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher

media:content.media:description: An Allied Irish Banks branch in Dublin.

item.title: Thailand Plans Finance Industry Tax Cuts to Build Frontier Hub
item.description: Thailand is planning to lower taxes and cut red tape to help it become a financial hub for investors doing business regionally, especially in frontier markets like Cambodia, Laos and Myanmar.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana, Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Paopoom Rojanasakul Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: Reeves Weighs Reversing Non-Dom Inheritance Tax Changes, FT Says
item.description: Rachel Reeves is considering reversing a decision to charge inheritance tax on the overseas assets of non-doms, according to the Financial Times.
item.dc:creator: Leonard Kehnscherper

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves, UK chancellor of the exchequer, outside 11 Downing Street ahead of the presentation of the spending review in London, UK, on Wednesday, June 11, 2025. Reeves will defend her fiscal choices and trumpet billions of pounds of infrastructure investment in the UK spending review on Wednesday, as Keir Starmer's government seeks to regain momentum after a faltering first year in power. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: More Central Banks Than Ever Plan to Build Up Their Gold Hoards
item.description: A record share of the world’s central banks plans to accumulate more gold over the next 12 months, drawn by bullion’s performance during times of crisis and protection against inflation.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan

item.title: Global Euro Moment Needs Decisive Action, ECB’s Lagarde Says
item.description: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde called on policymakers to seize the moment and increase the euro’s global profile as Donald Trump’s policies undermines confidence in the US dollar.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde, president of the European Central Bank (ECB), at a rates decision news conference in Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, June 5, 2025. The ECB lowered interest rates for the eighth time in a year after inflation dipped beneath 2% and the economy suffered repeated blows from US tariffs. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg
